sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Clostridium difficile infection: 200 mg ORALLY twice daily with or without food for 10 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been studied in patients younger than 18 years of age

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• gender: no dose adjustment needed
  • geriatric: no dose adjustment needed
  • renal: no dose adjustment needed

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to fidaxomicin or any product component

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity reaction, acute (ie, dyspnea, pruritus, rash, angioedema of the face, mouth, and throat) has occurred; increased risk with history of macrolide allergy; discontinue use if severe reaction develops
  • lack of confirmation or strongly suspected Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea; increased risk of bacterial drug resistance
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (6%), Nausea (11%), Vomiting (7%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (2%), Neutropenia (2%)
Serious
Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction (less than 2%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (4%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Fidaxomicin, a locally-acting macrolide antibiotic, is bactericidal via inhibition of RNA polymerases primarily against Clostridia species including Clostridium difficile

0.title: Absorption
0.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 2 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: minimal
  • Effect of food: AUC unchanged

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal: more than 92% recovered changed and unchanged
  • Renal: 0.59% unchanged

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: resolution of symptoms of clostridium difficile infection is indicative of efficacy.

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Drug may cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or gastrointestinal hemorrhage.
